linkTarget.anchoringText: Drive mechanism rules production performance and recovery factor of oil and gas fields; typically, recovery factors and production performace by drive mechanism are shown in Figure 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Recovery Factor by Drive Mechanism. Vivian Reservoir under strong Waterdrive

formatted-caption.caption-text: Recovery Factor by Drive Mechanism. Vivian Reservoir under strong Waterdrive

linkTarget.anchoringText: Peruvian heavy oilfields are located in Marañón Basin, at the Northern Jungle of Peru. According to analysis of production history, they are under a strong waterdrive mechanism. A tipical production performance in Jibarito field is shown in Figure 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Production Performance of Jibarito Field under Water Drive Mechanism

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production Performance of Jibarito Field under Water Drive Mechanism

linkTarget.anchoringText: It is observed that oil productivity decreases rapidly as water cut arises; this is a consequence of the strong waterdrive mechanism, as well as, the absence of a selective completion. Figure N°3 shows a conventional well trajectory and completion in Jibarito Field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Well Completion and Trajectory of a Well in Jibarito Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well Completion and Trajectory of a Well in Jibarito Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: On the other hand, Figures N°4, N°5 and N°6 shows the history of deferment production rates in Jibarito, Jibaro and Yanayacu fields. It is worth pointing out that both annual and average history rates of production deferment overpass 5%, which is considered a traditional thereshold in production operations.

On the other hand, Figures N°4, N°5 and N°6 shows the history of deferment production rates in Jibarito, Jibaro and Yanayacu fields. It is worth pointing out that both annual and average history rates of production deferment overpass 5%, which is considered a traditional thereshold in production operations.

On the other hand, Figures N°4, N°5 and N°6 shows the history of deferment production rates in Jibarito, Jibaro and Yanayacu fields. It is worth pointing out that both annual and average history rates of production deferment overpass 5%, which is considered a traditional thereshold in production operations.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Integrated Workflow to loss Production Management - SH Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Integrated Workflow to loss Production Management - SH Field

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Monitoring Dashboard – Anomaly in SHSB-244U well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Monitoring Dashboard – Anomaly in SHSB-244U well

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Monitoring Dashboard – after Intervention in SHSB-244U well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Monitoring Dashboard – after Intervention in SHSB-244U well

linkTarget.anchoringText: The G field is a mature heavy oil field in Ecuador which started producing in 1996. The initial development plan included drilling horizontal wells through M1 sandstone, which is a high permeability reservoir, to increase drainage area and improve sweep efficiency of heavy oil that is produced under a regional water drive mechanism (see figure 10).

As an alternative, active inflow control devices (AICD) allows equalizing the influx of oil and waterby creating additional backpressure in zones that produces at higher rates. Heavy oil takes a relatively nonrestrictive path while water or gas (lower viscosity fluid) flows through a tortuous path causing a decrease in its flow rate; thus, improving recovery efficiency and increasing NPV (see figure 11).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Typical Completion Design of a Horizontal Well with AICD - G Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical Completion Design of a Horizontal Well with AICD - G Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: The application of AICD in G field by sectioning horizontal borehole in new wells, according to permeability and fluid saturation, contributed with reducing water cut in 6.5% and rise oil production by 13% (see figure 12 and table 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Reduction in Water Cut and Increase in Oil Production – G Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reduction in Water Cut and Increase in Oil Production – G Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: On the other hand, real time monitoring of ESP performance allows measuring pump efficiency and energy consumption (Kwh); some criteria with three ranges were defined to determine the proper consumption of energy. Based on this analysis, it is possible to determine automatically how efficient the oil production rate is in a well, as compared to the energy consumption required to generate this production. Therefore, it is possible to determine which wells are working ineficienlly, and eventually, when they would need an intervention to repair or replace its ESP (see Figure 13).

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: ESP system production performance screen – SA Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: ESP system production performance screen – SA Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Production deferment average rates in Jibaro, Jibarito and Yanayacu fields exceeds 7%. An implementation of a real-time monitoring program + an automatic ESP production performance system would be useful to reduce downtime production, enhance runlife of ESP pumps (currently in 700 days), as well as, to assure that pump performance keeps at proper design parameters. Figure 14 show pump operation curves of a conventional well in Jibarito field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Pump Operation Curves of a ESP Pump – Jibarito Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pump Operation Curves of a ESP Pump – Jibarito Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: According to well logs interpretation and structural section, the traditional completion system might be replaced by a completion with equalizers. For instance, in one of the horizontal wells of Yanayacu, there were identified 6 zones with potential use of AICD. that would be isolated with 7 packers. (see Figure 15 and Table 5)

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Alternative Completion System with Equalizers – Yanayacu Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Alternative Completion System with Equalizers – Yanayacu Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Results of numerical simulation assessment during 6 months of execution show potential benefits of an alternative completion system with AICD; water production shall be reduced by 15% while oil recovery would be increase by 10% (see Figure 16 and table 6)

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Results of using an Alternative Completion System with Equalizers – Yanayacu Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Results of using an Alternative Completion System with Equalizers – Yanayacu Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Horizontal drilling seems to be the most suitable technology to recover the heavy oil from Vivian reservoir in Marañón Basin. According to annual report of reserves @ Dic-2015, there is almost 14 MMSTB of proved undeveloped reserves that can be added to proved developed figures with horizontal wells in Jibaro and Jibarito fields (see figure 17); thus, recovery factor can increase by almost 3% (see table 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Development Plan with Horizontal Wells – Jibaro Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Development Plan with Horizontal Wells – Jibaro Field
